data.title: Linda Ronstadt (b. 1940s)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Linda Ronstadt born 1940s including ancestors + 1 photos + 1 genealogist comments + DNA connections + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Born 1940s.

Ancestors

[children unknown]

Profile last modified 23 Apr 2024 | Created 5 Aug 2017

This page has been accessed 3,875 times.

Biography

Linda Ronstadt was featured in Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, 2014.

The Queen of Rock & Roll and a Queen of Country Music. She is the most successful, female rock and roll and country star. One of the biggest-selling artists in music history, Linda Ronstadt has sold more than 100 million records spanning rock, country, and pop music. [1]

Linda Ronstadt was born on 15 July 1946 in Tucson, Arizona. She is the daughter of Gibby Ronstadt and Ruth Copeman. Linda learned to sing while growing up in her family and became quite an accomplished singer.

Linda has crossed over to many diverse genres including rock, country, light opera, and Latin. In 1977 at a Los Angeles Dodgers' World Series baseball game, she gave a highly regarded rendition of the Star Spangled Banner. [2] She is not only one of the most beloved country and rock singers, but also significant for assisting and collaborating with other artists including The Eagles.[3] Her musical hits include "Different Drum" with the Stone Poneys as well as sole hits, "Long, Long, Time", You're No Good", and "When Will I Be, Loved", and "Blue Bayou". [4]

She received Grammy Awards, American Music Awards, Academy of Country Music awards, an Emmy Award, and an ALMA Award. She also received nominations for a Tony Award and a Golden Globe award plus a Latin Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award and a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award. In addition to being inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fames, she was awarded the National Medal of Arts and Humanities and the Kennedy Center Honor for lifetime artistic achievements. With Dolly Parton and Emmylou Harris, the three of them received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for their work as the group Trio.

She had a relationship with California governor Jerry Brown in the mid-late 1970's, but they never married.

In the 1980s, Linda had a year-long relationship with George Lucas of Star Wars fame, and even had an engagement ring from him but they never married.[5]

Linda has 2 adopted children, Mary Clementine Ronstadt and Carlos Ronstadt.

Linda is still living.
